Stress responses: How the body and brain handle perceived threats / dysregulation to try to keep us safe
Fight#To confront (aggressive, defensive)Example - Desire to shout someone after sensory overloadFlight To escape / withdraw Example - Avoiding a daunting task with distractions Freeze Inability to act Example - Analysis paralysis Fawn Appeasing others Example - People pleasing, having a hard time saying no Flop To mentally or physically collapse Example - Blanking or complete loss of motivation while overloaded
title: Stress Responses

content:
Finding Neuro Terms list #1#Alexithymia#Difficulty identifying, understanding and describing your emotions / the emotions of others
Masking#The process of suppressing your natural feelings and behaviours, usually to try and fit in with social norms or to get through a situation (drama club- sbsk)
Rejection sensitive dysphoria Experiencing an intense emotional reaction to perceived rejection / criticism, regardless of how small Rejection Sensitivity: Explainer and Advice
Time blindness Difficulty in perceiving and managing time, often leading to challenges with estimating how long tasks take, prioritising, and meeting deadlines
Hyperfocus An intense fixation on an interest or an activity for a long period of time, often losing track of surroundings and finding it difficult to give attention to anything else
Burnout A state of mental, emotional, and physical exhaustion caused by a long period of stress, often from being in a high-pressure environment for an extended time
Misophonia Experiencing an intense emotional reaction (often anger) to certain sounds
Thought-loops Cycles of repetitive thinking that keep returning to the same topics or concerns, usually without a set end point or resolution
Procrastination Becoming stuck delaying tasks / decisions, even if knowing that this delay will have negative consequences
Dopamine A neurotransmitter that is important in regulating motivation, enjoyment and reward
Maladaptive behaviour A behaviour which provides some short-term relief but does more harm than good in the long-term
Distress-tolerance The ability to endure and overcome emotional discomfort without using harmful coping strategies
Positive deviance: Reflecting on times when, despite challenging circumstances, things worked out well, to see what can be learned or replicated. If we only manage to do something one day a week, it’s common to feel shame and beat ourselves up over the 6 days we didn’t manage it, rather than looking at why and how we managed to succeed on that one day.
title: Terms List
